channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15708] Docker for dev-support scripts
item.description: Scripts in dev-support are limited in terms of dependencies by what's installed on apache machines. Installing new stuff is not easy. It can be painful even importing simple python libraries like 'requests'. This jira is to add a single docker instance which we can tweak to build the right environment for dev-support scripts.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Current patch only adds the dependency where we recently hit the wall, 'import requests' in report-flakies.py.

Also, it might be confusing to have following structure:
dev-support/Dockerfile
dev-support/hbase_docker.sh
dev-support/hbase_docker/Dockerfile

Maybe we can put all the hbase_docker stuff (which builds hbase and runs hbase_shell in a docker) in a separate directory 'hbase_in_docker'.

-1 overall

This message was automatically generated.

the precommit ASF license header check is correct, you should add one.

Is the goal to use this in the existing precommit jobs or just in standalone jobs?

What do you think would be better?
I am not sure how yetus' docker is setup, so i was thinking from a limited perspective and imagining it useful only for standalone jobs.

It can be painful even importing simple python libraries like 'requests'.

What's so hard about pip install --user requests ? I find docker to be a relative pain to use, especially on a mac.shrug
is that allowed on apache machines?

Our local machines where we can install anything anytime, is not the target use here. It's the apache machines (where I believe INFRA tickets are required to get stuff installed?). Since it'll be used only in jenkins, it should affect local env or dev productivity in any way.
I agree that a single pip install may not seem much at this point, but since the setup will allow us to import any deps in future, it will only become more and more useful.
That said, if we can get away with pip install --user requests this time, i'll be glad with that. Can someone confirm if policy allows us to do that on apache machines?

What we can do on the machines and what is a good idea are two different things. Folks with login access on builds.apache.org are given pretty broad leeway. It's entirely possible that pip install --user will work with the jenkins user. However, we have no control over what other folks with login access install in the jenkins user's python, nor even what version of python shows up.

In the interest of build stability, given the limitations of running within ASF infra's supported jenkins instance, please rely on docker.
I didn't realize the intended target environment was jenkins. This seems reasonable for jenkins.

+1 overall

This message was automatically generated.
Use a single run command. That will keep the layers down.
Didn't understand. Elaborate a bit please?
I think Elliott means that you can combine the three RUN invocations into a single RUN that relies on && to chain the commands you want to run.
I should note that I don't know enough about Docker to know the practical difference in resources used between a single RUN and multiple RUNs.

The resulting filesystem/environment after each run is stored and then layered on top of each other to create the final result. If the run commands are not complicated and there's no use for the intermediate state, then chaining all the commands together into a single run command will save space, and allow the docker image to start a little faster.

Ahh yes, when i saw docker build output, i was wondering if it's taking 4x space.
Here's the output for reference

Sending build context to Docker daemon   256 kB

Step 1 : FROM ubuntu:14.04

 ---> 8fa7f61732d6

Step 2 : ADD . /hbase/dev-support

 ---> Using cache

 ---> 895898147bd5

Step 3 : RUN apt-get -y update

 ---> Using cache

 ---> 447a208ea6e4

Step 4 : RUN apt-get -y install curl python-pip

 ---> Using cache

 ---> be899d8a6369

Step 5 : RUN pip install requests

 ---> Using cache

 ---> dea1d4cb1725

Successfully built dea1d4cb1725

Attached patch v4.
Here's the short output (after i already built once)

Sending build context to Docker daemon   256 kB

Step 1 : FROM ubuntu:14.04

 ---> 8fa7f61732d6

Step 2 : ADD . /hbase/dev-support

 ---> Using cache

 ---> ab1a8af699e3

Step 3 : RUN apt-get -y update && apt-get -y install curl python-pip && pip install requests

 ---> Using cache

 ---> f4b132aeed1b

Successfully built f4b132aeed1b

Two quick things, Appy:

  • As a best practice,iInstead of directly putting modules into your pip call, use pip install -r requirements.txt (and add a requirements file into dev-support).
  • Break up the RUN to avoid long lines and be more readable. A common way to do this would be: 
    RUN apt-get -y update \

    && apt-get -y install curl python-pip \

    && pip install requests

    Otherwise, LGTM.

v5.
Broke up the RUN line.

requirements file seem like something you'd want to do when there are many dependencies. Our project doesn't have enough python stuff that we need a separate file just to manage dependencies. I'd rather keep pip install unless we have quite a few (em, 5+ ?) python dependencies.

v6
i guess no harm in having a python-requirements.txt. Adding it.
requirements.txt probably shouldn't refer to Dockerfile? Guessing a sloppy copy and paste? After that's fixed, +1 from me.

argh, stupid me.
updated new patch v7.
Pushed. Thanks Appy and Dima Spivak for review.

+1 overall
